data: PED NIA ED Acute Mild Pain
Status
Nurse Independent Activities
Refer to Decision Support Tool: Pain Management: Acute Mild
Not applicable if:   - Oncology patient  - Patient has potential surgical problem
Patient Care
Use a standardized pain scale, such as verbal rating scale (0 to 10) or faces pain scale
Acute mild or moderate pain (pain intensity equal to or less than 4 on a 0 to 10 pain assessment tool)
Medications
Patient must be 3 months of age or older for acetaminophen administration
No history of acetaminophen administration in last 4 hours
If only giving one, ibuprofen is preferred if safe to give. Administer both acetaminophen and ibuprofen if none previously given and or dose due.
None
acetaminophen
15 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
acetaminophen
15 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: oral liq, first dose: NOW
acetaminophen
20 mg/kg, rectal, once, drug form: supp, first dose: NOW
Patient must be 6 months of age or older for ibuprofen administration
No history of ibuprofen administration in last 6 hours
No history of other NSAID administration in the last 8-12 hours (e.g. ibuprofen)
ibuprofen
10 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: oral liq, first dose: NOW
ibuprofen
10 mg/kg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
Communication Orders
Notify Treating Provider
To obtain ongoing orders for acute mild pain
